body: 是的
支持一下，希望后续的支持也能给力。
这很好

It seems that gflags has modified its namespace from google to gflags (see https://github.com/gflags/gflags/issues/145). 
We will resolve this in the future, right now you'd better use an old version of gflags(before 2.2) to compile brpc.
Sorry for the inconvenience.
支持.NET Core么
目前没有这样的编译环境:(.. 方便的话在 src/butil/class_name.cpp  里面加上. #include <butil/class_name.h> (这样这个编译单端能看到函数声明)。 并尝试再次编译.

解决了，原因是因为在模板函数class_name_str()内部声明了std::string demangle(const char*)这个函数，这个好像是gcc 5的bug：在模板内部声明的std::string不会有[abi:cxx11] tag，[这里](https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=69621)有个相似问题描述。
解决方法就是删除class_name_str()内部的demangle()函数声明
至少支持下 python，java 的客户端吧？
py, java都是支持的，但目前还在整理http2和rdma相关的代码，这个优先级更高一点。另外，使用pb的服务都可以被http+json访问，比如py中用http访问就行了。
server端支持[https](https://github.com/brpc/brpc/blob/master/docs/cn/http_service.md#开启https), 另外从实现角度，任何协议都可以开启SSL。
文档真的很给力，超赞~ @jamesge
@jamesge 好像没看到通信协议相关文档，类似 https://github.com/baidu/sofa-pbrpc/wiki/RPC%E5%8D%8F%E8%AE%AE 。
hope to see more documents in English
thanks
支持支持
Looks like it's duplicated with https://github.com/brpc/brpc/issues/6.  Please try update brpc.

atomic and memory order is not fully supported before gcc4.8(checkout https://gcc.gnu.org/gcc-4.7/cxx0x_status.html).  It's unsafe since memory order matters in brpc, You'd better try boost::atomic (which the internal version of brpc really uses),  instead of using std::atomic.
@chenzhangyi People all say that but nobody gives why. Does GCC under 4.8 have bugs on atomic and memory order? Is there any document or bug reporting marks that?

The link given by @chenzhangyi clearly states memory order is not supported in gcc4.4, so this patch will **not** be merged. However brpc can be built with gcc 3.4 and 4.4 inside Baidu, with deps on boost.atomic. It shouldn't be too hard to mimic that on this opensourced version. You can have another PR or fire an issue.

The code relates to many internal infra that are not opensourced right now, especially toolings to remotely control testing machines. The perf code will not be opensourced in near future and the link will be removed.

这个跨平台框架在互联网公司似乎用的很少，我们近期也不太可能重做性能测试（因为需要借用很多物理机器）。你如果使用ICE的话，其实可以自己做做对比。未必要像benchmark中那样特别严格，根据自己的场景，写一些demo code对比一下应该就差不多了。

要支持MAC OS，估计还得先迁移到C++11，不知道开发者是否有决心~
和C++11关系不大，迁移到MAC的主要问题在于epoll和futex需要做适配.

今天才得知brpc，好好研究下。。
嗯了解不多，感觉mutex、condition、thread等都进标准库了
不过貌似brpc对性能优化的比较高端，标准库可能满足不了？

但CPP11还是极大提高生产力的，lambda捕获变量咱也有closure了；
智能指针，基本告别new和delete，也算有gc了，还是实时、非搬迁、精准的gc；
std::function；auto和foreach等语法糖；
提高性能的std::move、emplace_back；
模板编程的一些辅助：std::enable_if，std::conditional等等

PS：util相关的一些东西觉得可以参考Facebook的folly。

In short, foo_bar() means the function does very little things and being very quick (mostly getter and setter). CamelCases means the function is not trivial.

会加的，之前是想省得用户多装一个cmake。
brpc本身一直支持c++11，没用c++11的东西是因为brpc其实是可以在gcc 3.4下编译和使用的（但要依赖boost.atomic）。随着百度的gcc版本逐渐突破三体人的技术封锁，相关代码也会逐渐调整。mac和win下的适配，主要是epoll适配到kqueue/poll/iocp，futex加模拟版本，fd做做抽象之类的。这种调整可能改起来很快也可能很慢，心急的可以自己尝试一下。
https://github.com/brpc/brpc/blob/master/docs/cn/bthread.md
gperftools changes its dir and namespace from google to gperftools in newer versions, try to manually change google to gperftools in source code temporarily. We'll verify this problem.

hi
Server可以[限制最大并发](https://github.com/brpc/brpc/blob/master/docs/cn/server.md#限制最大并发)  这里会谈到[雪崩的原因及对策](https://github.com/brpc/brpc/blob/master/docs/cn/avalanche.md) 限制最大并发是我们认为足够有效又足够简单的保护server的方案。
reopen this issue if something is wrong when you follow the guide.

Following table is from an un-opensourced document, comparing pros/cons of different methods to achieve concurrencies **at 2014**. **The judges on goroutine may not be true now(2017)**, just for a reference. People who know status quo of goroutines are welcomed to correct me.

**NOTE: we're assuming pthread impl. is 1:1**

| feature | pthread | callbacks | goroutine | bthread |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| gdb | supported | impossible | supported | supported |  
| local storage | yes | no | no | yes |
| exchange timeslice | no | no | no | yes // see note1 |
| priority | yes | no | no | no |
| efficiency of concurrency | low | very high | high // see note3 | high // see note2 |
| creation latency | 100us | 0.2us | not measured, should be quick enough | 0.2us |
| preemption | full | no | simple | no |
| easy-to-use | ok | bad | good | ok |
| max number | < 1000 | very high | lower than callbacks  | lower than goroutines |
| scheduling latency | 3-20us | 3-20us | 3us-10ms(gc) | 3-20us(more busy more lower) |

note1: exchange timeslice with the newly created thread to make it scheduled ASAP.

note2: parallelism is limited by #cpu-cores, can't be breakthrough by software, however concurrency can. The reason why bthread is more efficient at concurrency is **butex**, which makes blocking of bthread being separated from blocking of worker pthread. When a bthread blocks on butex, current worker pthread will continue to run other bthreads. For example, a server needs 200 pthreads(frequently blocking on mutexes/conditions) to maintain enough throughput, using bthread may lower number of worker pthreads to 8-24 (close to system load or #cpu-cores), however goroutine may still need ~200 workers(not true in 2017, see note3 below), because goroutines blocking on synchronizing primitives block underlying LWP directly.

note3: golang has a futex-like primitive now, https://github.com/golang/go/blob/b067ad939d9ba242c5c3bdd8a24220632311c6be/src/runtime/sema.go

Thanks for your reply! The table does help to deepen my understanding of bthreads. But in my understanding, Go also has a [scheduler](https://morsmachine.dk/go-scheduler) to ensure that blocking one goroutine  would not block the underlying kernel-level thread and it also uses [work-stealing](https://morsmachine.dk/go-scheduler) to take advantage of multi-core processors. (Please correct me if I'm wrong.)

work-stealing (steal half of the queue as I remembered) and scheduler does not solve the concurrency issue. I had read source code of go at then and didn't find anything similar with butex. Without a butex-like synchronizing primitive, mutex or condition can only be implemented with futex-like primitives (at best), and goroutine waiting for a mutex/condition (think about the client waiting for response in a sychronous RPC) blocks the underlying LWP, being less efficient at concurrency.

the impl. of SSL in brpc is at socket-layer, which means any protocol provided by brpc can be encrypted by SSL, provided [ServerOptions.ssl_options](https://github.com/brpc/brpc/blob/master/src/brpc/server.h#L264) is properly configured. However SSL client is not provided yet, check #37 for more.

Thanks for your reply! In my understanding, Go does not rely on synchronization primitives to ensure that the execution would never be blocked. Instead, this is done by the Go scheduler, which switch the context to another goroutine that is runnable when the current goroutine is blocked, according to [this article](https://morsmachine.dk/go-scheduler) . To do that, Go hooks all blocking system calls and users can only call the hooked version instead.
